Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "inaccurate "last updated" in package search results for packages with beta releases" (#6663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I noticed today that for the `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App` package, despite it being updated within the last 24 hours, the website still shows "last updated a month ago ". But when you go to the package page itself, it's clear that one of the versions, `2.1.6`, has "21 hours ago" in its "Last updated" column. This appears to be because the search results page is using the update timestamp of the version sorted, which is why right now, version `2.2.0-preview3-35497` is at the top.

Screenshots to demonstrate this:

![search_screen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7719209/48443815-44167800-e760-11e8-8196-0ced97fe7e63.png)
![package_screen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7719209/48443818-4678d200-e760-11e8-8e67-06782a4a0c92.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve register certificate experience - make it available during package upload" (#6704) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: More details soon

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "nuget.org should reject .symbols.nupkg" (#6662) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Today, if a user pushes a legacy symbol package (foo.symbols.nupkg) to nuget.org it gets published as a regular nuget package. We should reject it on the basis of the extension if there are no distinguishing elements in the nuspec.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGetDSR doesn't need Validation.Common.Job dependency" (#6592) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is a follow-up to: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1673

When JsonConfigJob was moved to Jobs.Common, DSR no longer needed the Validation.Common.Job dependency. I left it due to issue #1673, but that is almost resolved thanks to @joelverhagen.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature Request] Button "Download package with depedencies"" (#6700) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello,

It would be helpful, if there would be a button to download a package along with all dependencies in a single step.

Background:
We're developing in a LAN disconnected from Internet. On separate machines, we're downloading the required packages from nuget.org using the browser and pushing them in development LAN to our packet source server, afterwards. Especially with .net core there are a lot downloads required...

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[licenses 11/13] Limit Gallery to accept only OSI of FSF approved licenses" (#6623) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Licenses outside of OSI and FSF approved lists might be in quite a messy state and some of them are quite unusable for NuGet package publishing (see [Barr License](https://spdx.org/licenses/Barr.html) as an example). So until we decide how to handle those, we'll limit accepted licenses to OSI or FSF approved ones.

Needs https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7471

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Invalid constructor of FileNotFoundException is used in ZipArchiveExtensions" (#7555) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The following line throws `FileNotFoundException` and sets its `Message` to the file name:

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/70589cd27e3e2c6d38a017d61d9950506fd89df7/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Packaging/PackageExtraction/ZipArchiveExtensions.cs#L25

`FileName` property of the exception object ends up with `null`. It would be nice if well-formed exceptions were thrown.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Intermittent PackagingException errors on Ubuntu 18 - "file not found" even though it exists " (#7554) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We're intermittently seeing issues with NuGet throwing "File not found" errors, even though the file exists on disk. This appears to be unique to Ubuntu 18, and is intermittent.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe
dotnet.exe --version: 3.0.100-preview-009750
OS version: Ubuntu 18.04

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create an Ubuntu 18.04 machine
1. Clone https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCore
1. Run `./build.sh /p:SkipTests=true` in the repo root

### Verbose Logs

Here is one example of the error we get.

```
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error NU5019: File not found: '/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/src/Shared/Buffers.Testing/BufferSegment.cs'. [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error : NuGet.Packaging.Core.PackagingException: File not found: '/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/src/Shared/Buffers.Testing/BufferSegment.cs'. [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Packaging.PackageBuilder.AddFiles(String basePath, String source, String destination, String exclude) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Packaging.PackageBuilder.PopulateFiles(String basePath, IEnumerable`1 files) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Commands.MSBuildProjectFactory.CreateBuilder(String basePath, NuGetVersion version, String suffix, Boolean buildIfNeeded, PackageBuilder builder) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Commands.PackCommandRunner.BuildFromProjectFile(String path) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Commands.PackCommandRunner.BuildPackage(String path) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Commands.PackCommandRunner.BuildPackage() [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.PackTaskLogic.BuildPackage(PackCommandRunner runner) [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
[13:43:29]/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/sdk/3.0.100-preview-009750/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(199,5): error :    at NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.PackTask.Execute() [/mnt/work/e37dd45d8cd1eaf4/.dotnet/buildtools/korebuild/3.0.0-build-20181120.4/modules/sharedsources/sharedsources.csproj]
```
But this file definitely exists:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/49113930-b18bd380-f24b-11e8-976b-bce2094bf990.png)

cc @muratg @Eilon @ryanbrandenburg

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Allow project/solution setting to preference Nuget framework versions" (#7553) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Nuget allows packaging of multiple frameworks in a single Nuget, which is great. However, getting projects to start referencing something like Standard over Framework is a pain because the consuming Framework project will automatically pick up the Framework DLLs, even if you want it to start referencing the newer Standard DLLs. It would be great if you could set at a project or solution or nuget level a preference for what framework to target, then have fallbacks.

_This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/379356/allow-projectsolution-setting-to-preference-nuget.html VSTS ticketId: 726922_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Fiona Niu[MSFT] on 11/12/2018, 01:47 AM (15 days ago):

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion. We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further. You will hear from us in about a week on our next steps.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[spec] Client policy specification for signed packages" (#6426) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/%5BSpec%5D-NuGet-Package-Signing-Client-Policy

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Package update not found when updating via Visual Studio Solution" (#1827) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This problem occurs occasionally when trying to update nuget packages from the NuGet package manager within Visual Studio 2015, but only occurs when updating packages at the **solution** level; that is, right click on the solution (not the project), and choose "Manager NuGet Packages for Solution...".  It will find an update for a nuget package just fine and list the latest version, but after you select the projects to update and click the Install button, the installation fails with a message similar to the following in the Output window.

```
Package 'DansUtilityLibraries.CSharpLibrary' is not found in the following primary source(s): 'https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/'. Please verify all your online package sources are available.
```

Trying to do the install repeatedly just results in it failing with the same error.

Sometimes closing VS 2015 and reopening it will fix the problem and the install will succeed, but not all of the time.  I have found that the most reliable work around is to right-click the project and choose "Manager NuGet Packages..." and do the update from that window, for each project that needs the update. For some reason updating the nuget package at the project level does not have the same problem; it only occurs at the solution level.

I didn't think to try doing the update from the NuGet Package Manager PowerShell Console, so I'll give that a try as well next time it happens and update this ticket with the results.

I first ran into this problem months ago when I updated to VS 2015 and NuGet Package Manager 3, but now after installing VS 2015 Update 1 and NuGet Package Manager 3.3.0.167 the problem persists. As I mentioned above, the problem does not happen every time; it seems to be sporadic.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Error NU5125: The 'licenseUrl' element will be deprecated since VS 15.9" (#7509) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @Tornhoof on November 14, 2018 12:18_

## Steps to reproduce
Use <PackageLicenseUrl> in a SDK style project to specify the project's license.
1. Install VS 15.9 (SDK 2.1.500)
2. Clone https://github.com/Tornhoof/SpanJson.git
3. dotnet build -c Release

## Expected  behavior
Everything is builds and two nugets are created

## Actual behavior
Everything is builds and two nugets are created
and I get:
NU5125	The 'licenseUrl' element will be deprecated. Consider using the 'license' element instead.	SpanJson	C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.500\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets	202	

What is the expected replacement here, I don't specify "licenseUrl" in my csproj, I use PackageLicenseUrl, which is apparently the "right" way according to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/library-guidance/nuget

Is https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCore/issues/3751 by @natemcmaster  the correct solution for now to get rid of that error?

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Dll's packed as contentFiles can be referenced in a consumer project" (#7551) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe
NuGet version: 4.5.1.4879
dotnet.exe --version: 2.1.402
OS version: win10 v1809 (17763.134)

Dll's packed as content with build action content or none can be referenced by consumer projects.
My use case is packing a self-contained health checking application for a process which runs on Docker.
I can't deliver the application as a NuGet package, as the application which is including it will reference the dlls from the self contained application and fails to build as they are incompatible.

## Repro Steps

1. Pack netcore2.1 system dll's as contentFiles (build action none or content). I've been using System.Core.dll

2. Include the package in a project. targeting net47.

3. The packaged dlls will be referenced by the project if it would have a reference to the net47 version of the dll.

OR

1. Download and build attached Consumer.csproj.

If you take a look at a binlog, the System.Core.dll from the package is being chosen as a reference. The uploaded System.Core.dll is for netcore2.1

### Sample Project
[NugetRepro.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2617317/NugetRepro.zip)

There are two projects here - Package.csproj, from which I created a package using dotnet pack, and Consumer.csproj, which I build using dotnet build. If you generate a binlog, the packed dll is being used as a reference.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "LicenseAcceptanceWindow and LicenseFileWindow Accessibility issues" (#7452) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
from @PatoBeltran  in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/2495#issuecomment-434468385
- The accessibility for both the license window and the expanded license acceptance window seems to be broken, I suggest doing the following:
  - [x] Fix any issues that appear in Keros for these windows
  - [x] Make sure you can use narrator to navigate the UI three in both windows and get everything read
  - [x] Look into the live region event to announce to the user that the license acceptance window has expanded. **_Live region is not available in net46_**.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to dotnet restore from a private VSTS feed w/ SDK 2.1.500 - the credentials are not encoded" (#7516) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @jarz on November 14, 2018 17:55_

# Unable to dotnet restore from a private VSTS feed

In Azure DevOps (VSTS) I'm unable to use the latest SDK (2.1.500) to build my project, as it relies upon a package in my private feed. However, if I use SDK 2.1.403 the build succeeds.

I see a `401 Unauthorized` in the log. My account has the _Package Management_ license assigned (and it'd be a `402 Payment Required` if I didn't).

I use the .NET Core Installer task at the beginning of my build pipeline.

Log: https://gist.github.com/jarz/56d3ec2b0e3c1417a1c01168408d32bd
